normal.statement: Which of the following is the most abundant organic compound on Earth?
What type of bond joins amino acids together in proteins?
Which biomolecule serves as the primary energy currency of the cell?
What is the basic monomer unit of nucleic acids?
Which level of protein structure is determined by the sequence of amino acids?
What type of lipid forms the main structural component of cell membranes?
Which carbohydrate is the main storage form in animals?
What is the function of enzymes in biological systems?
Which nitrogenous base is found in RNA but not in DNA?
What type of reaction breaks down polymers into monomers?
Which structural level of proteins involves alpha-helices and beta-sheets?
What is the main function of triglycerides in living organisms?
Which sugar is known as blood sugar?
What determines the specificity of an enzyme for its substrate?
Which type of nucleic acid carries genetic information from DNA to ribosomes?
What is the basic structure of a nucleotide?
Which level of protein structure involves multiple polypeptide chains?
What type of bond joins monosaccharides in disaccharides?
Which lipid is characterized by a four-ring structure?
What is the role of tRNA in protein synthesis?
Which factor can denature proteins by disrupting hydrogen bonds?
What is the function of cholesterol in cell membranes?
Which carbohydrate is indigestible by humans and forms dietary fiber?
What is the effect of competitive inhibitors on enzyme activity?
options: Both increase Km and decrease Vmax

normal.statement: Which nitrogenous base pairs with thymine in DNA?

moderate.statement: What is the significance of the antiparallel arrangement in DNA double helix?
How do saturated and unsaturated fatty acids differ in their physical properties?
options: Unsaturated fats are solid at room temperature
Saturated fats are liquid at room temperature
Unsaturated fats have no double bonds
Saturated fats have higher melting points
moderate.answer: Saturated fats have higher melting points

moderate.statement: What is the role of cofactors in enzyme function?
options: They are the active site of the enzyme

moderate.statement: Which structural feature distinguishes RNA from DNA?
What is the effect of allosteric inhibitors on enzyme kinetics?
options: Both increase Km and decrease Vmax
Change the enzyme's shape and reduce activity
moderate.answer: Change the enzyme's shape and reduce activity

moderate.statement: How does the primary structure of a protein determine its final conformation?
options: It dictates the sequence of folding events
It has no effect on protein folding
It determines the chemical properties of side chains

moderate.statement: What is the significance of the peptide bond's partial double bond character?
options: It restricts rotation around the bond
It makes the bond more flexible
moderate.answer: It restricts rotation around the bond

moderate.statement: Which property of water makes it an excellent solvent for biological molecules?
What is the role of disulfide bonds in protein structure?
How do competitive and non-competitive inhibitors differ in their mechanism?
options: Both bind to the active site
Competitive bind to active site, non-competitive to allosteric site
moderate.answer: Competitive bind to active site, non-competitive to allosteric site

moderate.statement: What is the significance of Chargaff's rules in DNA structure?
How do enzymes lower the activation energy of reactions?
options: By providing an alternative reaction pathway
moderate.answer: By providing an alternative reaction pathway

moderate.statement: What is the function of molecular chaperones in protein folding?
Which structural feature allows phospholipids to form bilayers spontaneously?
What is the role of ribozymes in biological systems?
How does temperature affect enzyme activity?
What is the significance of the genetic code being degenerate?
options: One codon for multiple amino acids
Multiple codons for same amino acid
moderate.answer: Multiple codons for same amino acid

moderate.statement: Which forces maintain the tertiary structure of proteins?
options: Hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic interactions, disulfide bonds
moderate.answer: Hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic interactions, disulfide bonds

moderate.statement: What is the function of regulatory enzymes in metabolic pathways?
How does pH affect enzyme activity?
options: pH has no effect on enzymes
All enzymes have same pH optimum
Enzymes work only at neutral pH
Each enzyme has specific pH optimum
moderate.answer: Each enzyme has specific pH optimum

moderate.statement: What is the role of ATP in coupled reactions?
Which property makes cellulose indigestible by humans?
What is the significance of the induced fit model of enzyme action?
options: Enzyme changes shape to accommodate substrate
Enzyme and substrate are rigid structures
moderate.answer: Enzyme changes shape to accommodate substrate

moderate.statement: How do nucleic acids store and transmit genetic information?
What is the function of lipoproteins in the body?
Which factor primarily determines the specificity of enzyme-substrate interaction?

hard.statement: What is the thermodynamic basis for the spontaneous formation of lipid bilayers?
How does the Michaelis-Menten equation describe enzyme kinetics?
options: Hyperbolic relationship between velocity and substrate
Linear relationship between velocity and substrate
hard.answer: Hyperbolic relationship between velocity and substrate

hard.statement: What is the molecular basis for the cooperativity in hemoglobin oxygen binding?
How do prions cause disease despite having no genetic material?
options: They induce misfolding of normal proteins
hard.answer: They induce misfolding of normal proteins

hard.statement: What is the significance of the wobble hypothesis in translation?
options: Allows flexibility in third base pairing
Allows multiple tRNAs to recognize same codon
Explains why genetic code is not universal
hard.answer: Allows flexibility in third base pairing

hard.statement: How does the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation relate to buffer systems in biological fluids?
options: Relates pH to ratio of conjugate acid-base pairs
hard.answer: Relates pH to ratio of conjugate acid-base pairs

hard.statement: What is the structural basis for the different functions of myoglobin and hemoglobin?
How do competitive inhibitors affect the Lineweaver-Burk plot?
What is the role of ubiquitin in protein degradation?
How does the fluid mosaic model explain membrane dynamics?
options: Only lipids can move in membranes
Lipids and proteins can move laterally
hard.answer: Lipids and proteins can move laterally

hard.statement: What is the thermodynamic driving force for protein folding?
How do allosteric effectors regulate enzyme activity?
What is the molecular basis for the different melting temperatures of DNA with varying GC content?
options: GC pairs have three hydrogen bonds
GC pairs have two hydrogen bonds
hard.answer: GC pairs have three hydrogen bonds

hard.statement: How does the primary structure of collagen contribute to its tensile strength?
options: High glycine content allows tight packing
Regular repeating sequence facilitates triple helix formation

hard.statement: What is the significance of the proteasome in cellular regulation?
options: Degrades regulatory proteins to control cell cycle
hard.answer: Degrades regulatory proteins to control cell cycle

hard.statement: How do enzyme kinetics change in the presence of uncompetitive inhibitors?
options: Increase Km, no change in Vmax
No change in Km, decrease Vmax

hard.statement: What is the role of molecular recognition in biological systems?
options: Specific interactions based on complementary shapes
hard.answer: Specific interactions based on complementary shapes

hard.statement: How does the structure of tRNA facilitate its function in translation?
options: Cloverleaf structure with anticodon and amino acid attachment sites
hard.answer: Cloverleaf structure with anticodon and amino acid attachment sites

hard.statement: What is the biochemical basis for the different blood types in humans?
options: Specific carbohydrate antigens on red blood cells
hard.answer: Specific carbohydrate antigens on red blood cells

hard.statement: How do molecular chaperones distinguish between properly and improperly folded proteins?
options: By recognizing specific amino acid sequences

hard.statement: What is the role of post-translational modifications in protein function?
How does the structure of antibodies enable specific antigen recognition?
What is the significance of alternative splicing in protein diversity?
options: Allows single gene to produce multiple proteins
hard.answer: Allows single gene to produce multiple proteins

hard.statement: How do lipid rafts affect membrane protein function?
What is the molecular mechanism of enzyme catalysis?
